item.title: CV/
item.description: Please find below an abridged version of my CV. You can download a full PDF version from here. George Pacheco Evolutionary Biologist CEES / Blindernveien 31, 0371 Oslo ‚Ä¢ Norway george.pacheco@ibv.uio.no Initially trained in Biology in the Brazilian Northeast, I have worked on several projects in the vein of animal evolutionary genomics investigating a diverse range of taxa ‚Äî from tiny Collembolans to culturally evolving killer whales, which has given me a vast experience in the molecular lab and a fair understanding of the rationale behind bioinformatic analyses.

item.title: George Pacheco, PhD
item.description: George Pacheco, PhD Centre for Ecological and Evolutionary Synthesis ‚Äî University of Oslo Blindernveien 31, 0371 Oslo ‚Ä¢ Norway The best way of getting a hold of me is through my institutional email: george.pacheco@ibv.uio.no. Please write to me through it and I will get back to you as soon as possible.

item.title: News/
item.description: 08 Jul 2024/ I am back to Oslo to enjoy the Scandinavian summer! I really enjoyed my time visiting the lab of Prof. Kitano at NIG, sampling & touristing in Japan, but I am also happy to be back to Norway! üá≥üá¥ üå°Ô∏è üèñÔ∏è 23 Mar 2024/ After my well-deserved time in Brazil visiting family & attending a national conference, I am finally back to Norway. I returned already going to Bod√∏ to serve as a lecturer in the 2024 PhD Course in Population Genomics at the Nord University but I am now back to Oslo and looking forward to resuming my postdoctoral activities.

item.title: Publications/
item.description: Please find below an abridged version of my list of publication (please note that only the 3 first co-authors are displayed). You can download a detailed PDF version from here. In Preparation/ On the Origin and Spread of Feral Pigeons. Pacheco , Vieira, Martin et al. Submitted/ Understanding Human-Commensalism Through an Ecological and Evolutionary Framework. Fawthrop, Cerca, Pacheco et al. Submitted to Trends in Ecology & Evolution. Dog Introgression Drives Wolf Adaptation to Human-dominated Landscapes.

item.title: Reads/
item.description: I read quite a few Science Communication books throughout my bachelor times in Natal. Undoubtedly, titles such as The Drunkard's Walk and Lonely Planets greatly contributed to my initial scientic education. Although I still very much harbour a desire to read on various scientific subjects (I really like Physics, for instance), at some point one must focus on a specific field considering the short half-life of a human begin, and thus my reading of this kind of genre is no longer as diverse as it once was.

item.title: Research/
item.description: So far in my scientific carrer I have mainly worked on projects in the vein of Animal Evolutionary Genomics. To some of these I chiefly collaborated with wetlab work, while to others my contribution was on the drylab front, and yet to other projects I wore both the wetlab and the drylab hats (that was certainly the case for those projected I led). You will find below a selected list of the projects I have participated alongside with a short explaination on how I contributed to each of them.
